College of New Energy China University of Petroleum (East China) 66 West Changjiang Road Qingdao China Graphical abstract Ce-Nb-Ti metal oxide catalysts (CeNbTi) were synthesized for NH3-SCR by impregnation (IM), co-precipitation (CP) and solid process (SP) methods and characterized by various techniques. The results of NH3-SCR activity evaluations showed that CeNbTi-IM possessed the superior NH3-SCR performance in different gas hourly space velocity and better resistance to SO2 and potassium. The characterization results showed that the CeNbTi-IM catalyst had relatively high concentrations of Ce3+ and chemisorbed oxygen, strong synergistic effect among different components and well dispersed active species. More importantly, the catalyst had stronger reduction capacity and a large number of Lewis acid sites, which contributed to its excellent catalytic performance. The in situ DRIFTS results revealed that the impregnation method was beneficial to the adsorption of weakly adsorbed NO2, bidentate nitrate and NH3 species. In addition, it was revealed that the reaction paths over CeNbTi-IM, CeNbTi-CP and CeNbTi-SP obeyed both Langmuir-Hinshel wood and Eley-Rideal mechanisms, but the impregnation method could accelerate the reaction between pre-adsorbed ammonia/NO x species and NO x species/ammonia. Keywords Selective catalytic reduction NO NH3 Ce-Nb-Ti catalyst Preparation method 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides from the burning of fossil fuels as a major atmospheric pollutant are important causes of many environmental problems such as acid rain, photochemical smog formation, stratospheric ozone depletion, and the greenhouse effect [1–3]. Selective catalytic reduction of NO x with NH3 (NH3-SCR) has become an effective technology for removing NO x in the flue gas from stationary and mobile sources [4,5]. Although V2O5/TiO2-based catalysts have been commercialized worldwide in NH3-SCR [5,6], they are still confronted with a number of problems including the toxic effect of vanadium, a limited operating temperature window [7], the oxidization of SO2 to SO3, and the over-oxidation of NH3 to N2O [8]. Therefore, it has been of tremendous interest to develop a novel environment-friendly catalyst with excellent SCR performance. Recently, ceria has received substantial attention in NH3-SCR as different roles due to its non-toxicity and relatively low price [9,10], such as CeO2/Ti O2 [11,12], Ce O2/Al2 O3 [13,14], MnO x -NbO x -CeO2 [15], CeO2-MoO3/TiO2 [16,17], CeO2-WO3/TiO2 [18,19] and NbO x /CeO2-ZrO2 [20]. Ce-containing oxide catalysts have been widely proved to have excellent capacity for storing and releasing reactive oxygen via a mutual conversion between Ce4+ and Ce3+, which greatly contributes to excellent SCR activity [21,22]. Furthermore, the doping of Nb was reported to improve SCR performance of catalysts on account of the increased acidity and redox capacity [23–25]. In our previous studies, we prepared Ce-Nb-Ti catalysts with excellent NH3-SCR performance by an impregnation method [26]. Although the promotional impact of Nb on CeO2-TiO2 oxides catalyst in NH3-SCR reaction has been found, there is no research dealing with the effect of preparation methods on Ce-Nb-Ti catalyst for NH3-SCR. While it has been established that catalyst preparation method is an important factor to influence the loading and dispersion of active constituents, and their interaction [27–30]. Liu et al. [29] found that compared with the sol-gel method, the CeO2–W O3 catalysts prepared by the impregnation method and solid processing method possessed better catalytic activity because of larger specific surface area and stronger surface acidity. Ning et al. [30] synthesized CeO2–ZrO2–WO3 catalysts using four different methods, and found that they had different morphologies, element ratios, the concentration of chemisorbed oxygen species and surface acidity. Therefore, it is indispensable to thoroughly explore the effect of preparation method on Ce-Nb-Ti catalyst for NH3-SCR. In this work, we systematically investigated Ce-Nb-Ti oxide catalysts prapared by three methods including an impregnation method, co-precipitation method and solid process method for NH3-SCR reaction. The physicochemical properties of various catalysts were characterized by BET, XRD, XPS, TEM, H2-TPR and NH3-TPD. In addition, the possible reaction mechanism was explored by in situ DRIFT. This study focused on exploring how the differences in preparation methods affect the structure, acidity and redox behavior of Ce-Nb-Ti catalysts, and the relationship between these properties and catalytic activity was also investigated. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalysts preparation 2.1.1 Impregnation method (IM) All the chemicals were supplied by Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd (China). A calculated amount of C10H5NbO20 (2.024 g) was thoroughly dissolved in deionized water with continuous stirring at 60 ℃. Subsequently, Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (1.892 g) was dissolved in the solution at room temperature, and then citric acid (0.78 g) was added for complexation (the molar ratio of total precursor to citric acid was 2:1). Next, 5.0 g of the commercial TiO2 powder was immersed into the above solution. After ultrasonic treatment for 40 min, the mixture continued to be agitated sufficiently in a water bath at 80 °C until dehydrated. Finally, the obtained sample was dried at 110 ℃ for 12 h and then calcined at 500 °C for 5 h in an air atmosphere. The product was denoted as CeNbTi-IM, and the mass ratio of CeO2/Nb2O5/TiO2 was 15:10:100. The other two samples had the same mass ratio of CeO2/Nb2O5/TiO2 as CeNbTi-IM. 2.1.2 Co-precipitation method (CP) 1.016 g of niobium chloride was dissolved in alcohol under stirring at 60 ℃. Then 1.892 g of cerium nitrate and 15.018 g of titanium sulfate were successively dissolved in deionized water at room temperature. After evenly mixing the two solutions, excessive urea solution was slowly poured into the mixture and then continuously stirred for 9 h at 90 ℃. The resulting flocculent mixture was sealed and remained stationary for 48 h for complete precipitation. The precipitate was filtered and rinsed thoroughly with deionized water. Finally, the product was dried and calcined under the same conditions as above. The sample was denoted as CeNbTi-CP. 2.1.3 Solid process method (SP) Niobium oxalate (2.024 g), cerium nitrate (1.892 g) and TiO2 (5.000 g) were mixed and ground in an agate mortar. After crushed for 30 min in a grinder, the mixture was calcined at 500 °C for 5 h. The sample was denoted as CeNbTi-SP. The K2O-poisoned catalysts samples were synthesized via impregnating CeNbTi catalyst with potassium nitrate solution. After the excess water was evaporated, the mixture was dried for 12 h at 110 °C and calcined at 500 °C for 5 h. The molar ratio of K/Ce was 0.1. 2.2 Catalyst activity evaluations The SCR activity evaluations were operated in a fixed-bed quartz flow reactor (d = 8 mm) at 150−500 °C using 0.20 g catalysts (60–100 mesh). The feed stream contained 1000 ppm NO, 1000 ppm NH3, 3 vol.% O2, 500 ppm SO2 (when used) and N2 as balance gas. Under ambient conditions, the mixed gas was introduced into the reactor and the total flow rate was controlled to 500 mL/min. A 350 Pro gas analyzer (Testo Corp.) continually monitored the concentrations of gases. The NO conversion was calculated as follows: N O c o n v e r s i o n = N O i n - N O o u t N O i n × 100 % 2.3 Catalysts characterization N2 adsorption/desorption were performed on an ASAP2020-M automatic gas sorption system (Micromeritics Instrument Corp.) to obtain the BET surface area and pore characteristics of samples at 77 K. Before the adsorption operation, the catalyst sample was degassed in the N2/He mixture at 300 ℃ for 4 h. The crystal structures of the catalysts were measured by X-ray diffractometer with a X’Pert PRO system using Cu Ka (λ =0.15406 nm) radiation at 40 kV and 40 mA. The XRD diffraction patterns were recorded over a 2θ range of 10–80 ° with a scanning rate of 4°/min. The valence states of the chemical elements contained in samples were identified by X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) using a Thermo ESCALAB 250 spectrometer with Al Ka radiation (1486.6 eV). The binding energies calibration was checked by C1 s as an internal standard (BE =284.8 eV). Microstructures and lattice fringes of the catalysts were obtained on JOEL JEM-2100 F electron microscope. 1 mg of the sample powder was dispersed in ethanol and subjected to ultrasonic vibration for 30 min, then it was dropped on the carbon film copper mesh. TEM observation was carried out after the ethanol volatilized. The H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was carried out to analyze the reducibility of the samples in a FINESORB-3010 chemisorption analyzer. For each measurement, catalyst granule (50 mg, 60–100 mesh) was decanted into a quartz U-tube reactor (i.d. = 6 mm) and then treated in H2 (10 %)-Ar (30 mL/min) from room temperature to 800 °C with the rate of 10 °C/min. The NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) was used to analyze the surface acidity of samples in the same instrument as TPR. 50 mg of samples and 0.5 % NH3/He (30 mL/min, adsorbent) were used. The temperature was then increased to 700 °C in a rate of 10 °C/min in flowing He. The in situ DRIFT measurements were carried out on a FTIR spectrometer (Thermo Nicolet iS 50). The sample was placed in an IR cell and pretreated at 400 ℃ in Ar atmosphere for 2 h, and then it was cooled to 50℃. During the cooling process, the background spectra at certain temperature were collected and subtracted automatically from reflectance spectrum. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance 3.1.1 SCR catalytic activity The NO conversion of CeNbTi samples in the reaction temperature range of 150−500 °C at different GHSV exhibits in Fig. 1 . As shown in Fig. 1(a), the GHSV was 90,000 h−1, CeNbTi-IM exhibited best catalytic activity in the temperature range of 250−450 °C and 93.9–98.7 % conversion was achieved. The activity of CeNbTi-CP was slightly lower than that of CeNbTi-IM at 300−450 °C. By contrast, CeNbTi-SP catalyst showed a narrow temperature window and achieved high activities (92.8–98.1 %) at 300−450 °C. When reaction temperatures was lower than 300 °C, the activity of CeNbTi-SP was worst among the three samples. At the temperature higher than 450 °C, the catalytic activities deceased as follows: CeNbTi-IM > CeNbTi-SP > CeNbTi-CP. As exhibited in Fig. 1(b), the three samples exhibited slight NO conversion at the temperatures below 200 °C at a high GHSV of 200,000 h−1. With increasing temperature, the CeNbTi-IM catalyst exhibited optimal catalytic activity, and more than 92 % of NO conversion was achieved in the widest temperature window (250−500 °C). Compared with Fig. 1(a), the activity of CeNbTi-IM declined in low temperatures (150−250 °C), but was hardly affected at higher temperatures. In contrast, the catalytic activities over CeNbTi–CP and CeNbTi–SP catalysts decreased significantly with the increase of GHSV. It was clear that CeNbTi-IM could maintain high catalytic activity even at a high GHSV. It indicated that CeNbTi-IM has more strong adaptability to high GHSV. It could be seen that despite the same mass ratio of CeO2/Nb2O5/TiO2, the activity of the CeNbTi catalysts prepared by different methods is obviously different. This was because preparation methods would lead to the difference in the physicochemical properties of catalysts and the interactions among components. 3.1.2 Resistance of K2O Potassium exists usually in the emission from stationary sources including coal-, municipal solid waste (MSW) and biomass-fired power plants. Potassium was reported to be the most serious poison for V2O5/TiO2-based commercial SCR catalyst [31]. Therefore, the influence of K2O on various samples was studied, and the results are shown in Fig. 2 . Compared with Fig. 1(a), it could be seen that K2O could inhibited the SCR activity of CeNbTi-SP greatly and caused the decrease in the NO conversion from 97.9 % to 76.1 % at 350 °C. Although the NO conversion also dropped over CeNbTi-IM and CeNbTi-CP due to K2O doping, 90.3–98.6 % and 89.3–95.8 % NO conversion was still obtained at 275−450 °C, respectively. At high temperatures (400−500 °C), CeNbTi-IM exhibited the best resistance to K2O. 3.1.3 Effect of SO2 Fig. 3 presents the deactivation effect of SO2 on the catalytic activities of CeNbTi-IM, CeNbTi-CP and CeNbTi-SP. The NO conversion of CeNbTi-IM decreased with time and reached nearly 50 % after about 10.5 h in the presence of SO2. For CeNbTi-CP and CeNbTi-SP, the NO conversion dropped to 46.2 % and 43.6 % after about 10.5 h, respectively. After SO2 was cut off, almost no change in their NO conversion were found. It could be seen that the CeNbTi-IM sample showed a slightly better resistance to SO2. It was reported that the presence of SO2 gave rise to the formation of NH4HSO4, Ce (SO4)2 and Ce2 (SO4)3 [32]. NH4HSO4 could deposit on catalyst surface, occupy active sites and impede the SCR reaction on catalyst surface [33]. More seriously, Ce (SO4)2 and Ce2 (SO4)3 were difficult to decompose, and further disrupted the redox cycle between Ce3+ and Ce4+ due to their inactivation. However, the synthesis methods seemed to affect the formation of sulfate species on the CeNbTi samples slightly. 3.2 Characterization of catalysts 3.2.1 N2 adsorption/desorption and XRD analysis The BET specific surface area and pore characterization of CeNbTi-IM, CeNbTi-CP and CeNbTi-SP are presented in Table 1 . The order of BET surface area and pore volume was as follows: CeNbTi-CP < CeNbTi-IM < CeNbTi-SP, while the CeNbTi-IM catalyst has the largest pore size. It could be observed that preparation method significantly influenced the surface characteristics of CeNbTi catalysts. In comparison with Fig. 1, it was found that the catalytic activities did not show a similar tendency to the BET results. It indicated that BET surface area was not a dominating factor for CeNbTi-IM with superior performance. Fig. 4 displays the XRD patterns of the Ce-Nb-Ti oxide catalysts synthesized by different methods. The crystalline phases of samples were identified by referring to the JCPDS files (File No. 71-1166 for anatase TiO2; No. 75-1751 for rutile TiO2; No. 43-1002 for cubic CeO2; No. 27-1003 for niobium oxide). As for CeNbTi-CP, the characteristic peaks assigned to anatase TiO2 were observed, and some weak diffraction peaks of rutile phase TiO2, cubic CeO2 and cubic Nb2O5 were detected. Moreover, the diffraction peak of TiO2 was sharper and stronger, indicating that the crystallinity was higher and grain size was larger [34]. This result was consistent with the lower BET surface area of CeNbTi-CP. In contrast, besides anatase TiO2, only few cubic CeO2 or cubic Nb2O5 was found over CeNbTi-SP. Moreover, almost all the diffraction peaks become broaden and lower. For the diffraction pattern of CeNbTi-IM, only anatase TiO2 and cubic CeO2 was observed. In addition, it was clear that the characteristic peaks intensity of anatase TiO2 and cubic CeO2 over CeNbTi-IM was much lower than those over the other two samples were. It showed that the active species of Ce and Nb were distributed evenly and the crystallization of carrier TiO2 was inhibited. It meant that there was a relatively strong interaction among the species over CeNbTi-IM, which could be a reason why CeNbTi-IM exhibited the best activity. 3.2.2 XPS analysis The chemical states of the surface species on CeNbTi-IM, CeNbTi-CP and CeNbTi-SP catalysts were analyzed by XPS. The characteristic peaks of Ti 2p, Ce 3d, Nb 3d and O 1s are shown in Fig. 5 . The binding energies of two characteristic peaks of Ti 2p were 464.7 and 459.1 eV for CeNbTi-IM, respectively. For CeNbTi-CP and CeNbTi-SP, the binding energies of the Ti 2p3/2 peaks transferred to lower location and decreased to 464.5 and 458.9 eV, respectively. The binding energies of these peaks indicated that Ti appeared in the form of Ti4+ [35]. That is to say, Ti exist as Ti4+ regardless of the preparation methods of the Ce-Nb-Ti catalysts. In addition, the intensities of the Ti 2p peaks were different over the three samples, which was probably ascribed to the difference in the interaction among components. As shown in Fig. 5(b), the XPS spectra of Ce 3d could be divided into two tapes of 3d 3/2 and 3d 5/2, which labeled as u and v, respectively. Among the eight peaks, those peaks represented by u, u", u"' and v, v", v"' were assigned to Ce4+, while u' and v' were attributed to Ce3+ [36,37]. It is established that the existence of Ce3+ could create unsaturated chemical bonds, oxygen vacancies and a charge imbalance on catalyst. Accordingly, the chemisorbed oxygen or/and weakly bonded oxygen species absorbed on the catalyst surface increased [38,39]. The Ce3+ ratio of CeNbTi-IM (41.3 %), calculated by Ce3+/ (Ce3++Ce4+), was obviously higher than of CeNbTi-CP (39.5 %) and CeNbTi-SP (25.4 %). It suggested that the impregnation method contributed to more Ce3+ on catalyst surface. Therefore, CeNbTi-IM had better SCR performance than CeNbTi-CP and CeNbTi-SP. The Nb 3d XPS spectra over various CeNbTi samples are displayed in Fig. 5 (c). The peaks at 207.3 eV and 209.8 eV representing Nb 3d5/2 and Nb 3d3/2 were attributed to Nb5+ species [30]. The intensity of the two peaks over CeNbTi-IM catalyst was higher than those of CeNbTi-CP and CeNbTi-SP. It suggested the impregnation method changed the chemical environment around the Nb species in the catalysts. As presented in Fig. 5(d), the O 1s spectra of the CeNbTi samples were fitted by three lapped peaks. These lapped peaks could be classified as lattice oxygen (B.E. = 528.2–532.5 eV, denoted as Oα) [40], weakly adsorbed surface oxygen (B.E. = 529.0–532.5 eV, denoted by Oβ) [41] and surface oxygen by hydroxyl species and/or adsorbed water species (B.E. = 530.5–533.2 eV, denoted by Oγ) [42], respectively. The ratio of Oβ/ (Oα+ Oβ +Oγ) in CeNbTi-IM (39.3 %) was much higher than that in CeNbTi-CP (26.6 %) and in CeNbTi-SP (24.7 %). Because the weakly adsorbed surface oxygen is active in oxidation reactions, the higher Oβ ratio in CeNbTi-IM would facilitate the oxidation of NO, thereby accelerating the redox reaction through the “fast SCR” reaction [43]. It could be deduced that the best SCR activities of CeNbTi-IM catalyst resulted from the increase in surface adsorbed oxygen. 3.2.3 TEM analysis Fig. 6 shows the HR-TEM micrographs of the Ce-Nb-Ti oxide samples. The morphology and crystal structure of three catalysts were clearly represented in the micrographs. The three catalysts contained anatase crystal particles. As for CeNbTi-CP, there are four kinds of interplanar crystal spacing. 0.353(0.346) nm, 0.332 nm, 0.315 nm and 0.283 nm of interplanar crystal spacing belonged to anatase (101), rutile (110) [12], orthorhombic Nb2O5 (180) [23] and CeO2 (200) [25], respectively. This implied that the crystalline phases of TiO2, Nb2O5 and CeO2 existed in CeNbTi-CP, which was consistent with XRD results. Similarly, for CeNbTi-SP, 0.346 nm and 0.314 nm of lattice fringes belonged to anatase (101) phase and Nb2O5 (180) orthorhombic phase, respectively. However, only 0.358 nm (belonged to anatase (101) phase) and 0.283 nm (belonged to CeO2 (200) phase) of interplanar crystal spacing could be observed on the CeNbTi-IM surface, and the crystalline phase of TiO2 and CeO2 in CeNbTi-IM was much less than CeNbTi-CP. This meant that CeO2 particles were dispersed in CeNbTi-IM better than CeNbTi-CP. The absence of Nb2O5 phase further suggested the strongest interaction among species in CeNbTi-IM, which was consistent with the XPS results. 3.2.4 H2-TPR analysis Fig.7 shows the H2-TPR profiles of CeNbTi-IM, CeNbTi-CP and CeNbTi-SP. It was obvious that three peaks appeared over the CeNbTi-IM catalyst. The peak located at 415 °C was classified as the reduction of surface oxygen species [20,44], and the peaks at 505 °C and 683 °C could be classified as surface and bulk reduction of ceria, respectively [45–47]. For CeNbTi-CP and CeNbTi-SP, the reduction peaks of surface oxygen moved to higher temperatures (432 °C for CP and 501 °C for SP). The reduction peaks of ceria shifted from low temperature to high temperature, indicating a decrease on the reducibility of ceria [45]. Moreover, the onset temperatures (T onset) over CeNbTi-IM, CeNbTi-CP and CeNbTi-SP were about 281 °C, 332 °C and 310 °C, respectively. The lowest T onset over CeNbTi-IM implied that it could be reduced more easily. Furthermore, the impregnation method led to the prominent augment in the intensity and area of the primary reduction peak. These results confirmed that the CeNbTi-IM catalyst had excellent reduction capacity. By integrating the peak area, the calculated H2 consumption of CeNbTi-IM catalyst was higher than that of CeNbTi-CP and CeNbTi-SP (2.45:2.12:1), which was consistent with the SCR performance sequence. According to XPS results, the CeNbTi catalysts synthesized by the co-precipitation method and solid process method had less Ce3+ and weakly surface adsorbed oxygen. Therefore, it could be inferred that the difference in H2 consumption for different samples was likely to correlate with the change in the redox pair of Ce3+/Ce4+ and surface adsorbed oxygen, resulting from different catalyst preparation methods. 3.2.5 NH3-TPD analysis NH3-TPD were implemented to investigate the amount of the surface acids and the acid strength of the CeNbTi catalysts. As shown in Fig. 8 , all the three catalysts presented two NH3 desorption peaks in the profiles. The peak located in lower temperature represented the desorption of NH4+ on the Brønsted acid sites [48–50]. The other peak in higher temperature was attributed to the desorption of NH3 bound to Lewis acid sites [32,51]. Generally, the areas of desorption peaks in different temperature regions represented the relative amount of acid sites. The sequence of the amount of the Brønsted acid sites was derived by calculating the peak areas of the catalysts as follows: CeNbTi-CP > CeNbTi-SP > CeNbTi-IM. Interestingly, the peak area of NH3 attached to Lewis acid sites over CeNbTi-IM was larger than that of CeNbTi-CP and CeNbTi-SP samples obviously, which was consistent with the trend of the SCR activity. In addition, the desorption peak associated with Lewis acid sites over CeNbTi-IM shifted to higher temperature, suggesting the acid strength enhanced. In a word, the CeNbTi catalyst prepared by impregnation method not only increased the number of Lewis acid sites, but also enhanced the strength of Lewis acid sites. It has been proved that ammonia tends to adsorb on Brønsted acid sites at low temperature [52]. By contrast, Lewis acid sites have relatively high thermal stability. Consequently, the low temperature activity of catalyst is believed to be mainly attributed to Brønsted acid sites, while Lewis acid sites played a decisive role in higher temperature for the NH3-SCR reaction [53]. Abundant Lewis acid sites are conductive to the adsorption and activation of ammonia at high temperature [54,55]. In addition, Lewis acid sites have the ability to activate surface oxygen through electrostatic polarization [56], which is conducive to the oxidation of gaseous NO to NO2, thus promoting “rapid SCR” reaction. Accordingly, it could be speculated that the Lewis sites played a dominated role in SCR reaction for CeNbTi. 3.2.6 In situ DRIFT study 3.2.6.1 NH3 adsorption Fig. 9 displays the DRIFT result of NH3 adsorption for different CeNbTi catalysts at 150 °C. The bands at 1575 cm−1 and 1172 cm−1 corresponded to the asymmetric and symmetric bending vibrations of ammonia species combined with Lewis acid sites [57,58]. The bands at 1442 and 1666 cm−1 could be attributed to the asymmetric and symmetric bending vibrations of ionic NH4+ species combined with Brønsted acid sites [24]. The band at 1327 cm−1 belong to NH2. It was reported that NH2 plays the significant role as an intermediate for the high-temperature NH3-SCR reaction in “E-R” route [58–60]. The bands located at 3151, 3248 and 3372 cm-1 were classified as the NH stretching vibration modes [59]. A less obvious band located at 3681 cm-1 belong to the expending of surface hydroxyl groups [61]. Furthermore, an unobtrusive band located at 1952 cm−1 were observed, which belonged to the stretching mode of NbO in the overtone region [62]. The NbO overtones meant that the expending of NbO bond occurred during the SCR reaction. The DRIFTS spectra showed that the peak (about from 1350 to 1800 cm−1) for the catalyst synthesized by a co-precipitation method was bigger than that by the IM and SP methods, indicating relatively more Brønsted acid sites in CeNbTi-CP. It was consistent with the NH3-TPD results. 3.2.6.2 NO + O2 adsorption Fig. 10 shows the in situ DRIFT results of the co-adsorption of NO and O2 over the three CeNbTi catalysts. It has been demonstrated that the band located at 1612 cm−1 belonged to NO2, and the bands located at 1571 and 1250 cm−1 could be classified as bidentate nitrate [58–62]. Moreover, the band centered around 1358 cm−1 could be classified as free nitrate ions [63,64]. For CeNbTi-IM and CeNbTi-SP catalysts, it seemed that there was the same amount of the adsorption of NO x species, as shown in Fig. 10. Noticeably, an evident decline of the band intensity (1610 cm−1) could be observed on CeNbTi-CP catalyst, the bands located at 1557, and 1250 cm−1 nearly disappeared over CeNbTi-CP catalyst. That was to say, the CeNbTi catalyst synthesized by a co-precipitation method had a negative effect on the adsorption of NO x species. In addition, it had been demonstrated that the existence of adsorbed NO2 was highly conducive to the catalytic activity at low-temperature via the “fast-SCR” by facilitating the formation of intermediate nitrate species [65]. Moreover, at high temperatures, NO2 also played a significant role as an intermediate product of N2. Interestingly, the reaction process of CeNbTi-IM catalyst could produce more adsorbed NO2 than that of CeNbTi-CP at 150 °C. It suggested the enhanced ability of CeNbTi-IM sample towards NO activation, thereby promoting the catalytic activity. 3.2.6.3 Reaction of NO + O2 with pre-adsorbed NH3 The time-varying DRIFT spectra of the interaction between pre-adsorbed NH3 and NO + O2 on CeNbTi samples are shown in Fig. 11 . Generally, the amount of the NH3 species adsorbed on the catalysts decreased upon exposing in NO + O2, which indicated that adsorbed NH3 species were consumed by the reaction with gaseous NO x /surface N x O y species. As shown in Fig. 11(a), some adsorbed ammonia species emerged on CeNbTi-IM catalyst after NH3 pre-adsorption. It was found that NH3 species combined with Lewis acid sites (about 1300 and 1597 cm−1) and a few NH4 + species combined with Brønsted acid sites (about 1420 and 1665 cm−1) were present on the surface of CeNbTi-IM [66]. Moreover, coordinated NH3 species (1212 cm−1) and the stretching mode of Nb = O bond during the reaction process (1952 cm−1) formed on the CeNbTi-IM surface. After NO + O2 was introduced, it could be observed clearly that both Lewis acid sites and Brønsted acid sites faded away in 2 min, while some new bands (around 1258, 1577 and 1605 cm−1) due to NO x species appeared [65]. Interestingly, the NH3 species combined with Lewis acid sites (3151, 3248 and 3372 cm−1) also faded away after 2 min. This result indicated that the NH3 species was expended by N x O y species or gaseous NO x over CeNbTi-IM [59,60]. By contrast, the expending of the NH4 + (B) species was slower than that of the NH3 (L) species. The possible reason was that NH3 (L) played a significant role as an intermediate and reacted with gaseous NO. It implied that the SCR reaction acted up to Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism. For CeNbTi-CP and CeNbTi-SP catalysts, the similar phenomena were observed. The reaction path over them could also be attributed to E-R mechanism. As exhibited in Fig. 11(b) and (c), the new band located at 1359 cm−1 was classified as the intermediate transitions from the coalition of pre-adsorbed NH3 and NO x species [64]. Comparing the results displayed in Fig. 11, CeNbTi-IM exhibited a stronger activation capacity of NH3. In addition, the impregnation method might facilitate the production of NH3 species combined with Lewis acid sites (about 1212, 1300 and 1597 cm-1), which played a significant role as the intermediates among E-R reaction path. 3.2.6.4 Reaction of NH3 with pre-adsorbed NO + O2 The time-varying DRIFT results of the interaction between pre-adsorbed N x O y species and NH3 under the catalysis of CeNbTi catalysts are shown in Fig. 12 . As exhibited in Fig. 12(a), after NO + O2 adsorption, CeNbTi-IM catalyst was covered by bridging nitrates (1245 cm−1), bidentate nitrates (1571 cm−1), monodentate nitrates (1302 cm−1) and free nitrate ions (1359 cm−1). However, the subsequent addition of NH3 reduced the bands strengths located at 1575 and 1359 cm−1, and these bands transferred to the lower wavenumbers of 1530 and 1327 cm−1, respectively [61,62,66]. Furthermore, the bands strengths at 1530 and 1245 cm−1 gradually decreased with time. That is to say, the introduction of NH3 obviously let up the intensity of the pre-adsorbed N x O y species on CeNbTi-IM catalyst. Simultaneously, the peaks classified as NH4 + species combined with Brønsted acid sites (about 1420 and 1666 cm−1) appeared. These were also considered as L-H mechanism [67,68]. The existence of these bands meant that more active sites were produced, which was conducive to the adsorption and activation of NH3, resulting in higher catalytic activity. For CeNbTi-CP and CeNbTi-SP catalysts, the pre-adsorbed N x O y species were also appeared with the addition of NO + O2, and further reacted with gaseous NH3, are displayed on Fig. 12(b) and (c), respectively. After adding NH3, the strength of bands over CeNbTi-CP catalyst located at 1604 and 1359 cm−1 gradually weakened and transferred to 1575 and 1327 cm−1, respectively. These phenomena meant the effective expending of surface nitrate species. Hereafter there were a little adsorbed NH3 (L) species (3372, 3248, 3151 cm−1) and NH4 + (B) species (1666 and 1403 cm−1) appeared on the surface of catalysts. It is worth noting that the pre-adsorbed N x O y species (1527 cm−1) were changeless on the catalysts even after the addition of NH3 for 0.5 h. The possible reason was that there was an efficient reaction between NH3 and pre-adsorbed NO x species, which could be classified as the L-H mechanism. For CeNbTi-SP catalyst, its reaction path was similar to that of CeNbTi-IM and CeNbTi-CP and followed the L-H mechanism. Nevertheless, the intensity of the bands at 1575 and 1327 cm−1 was nearly not changed after the addition of NH3 for 0.5 h. It suggested that the excitation of NH3 was arrested by adsorbed NO x . Moreover, the nitrates related bands were obviously lower in intensity on CeNbTi-IM than that CeNbTi-SP after exposing in NO + O2 for 30 min. It confirmed again that CeNbTi-IM had more active sites for the adsorption and activation of NH3. 3.2.6.5 Reaction mechanism Based on in situ DRIFTS study, the reaction mechanism for NH3-SCR over CeNbTi-IM, CeNbTi-CP and CeNbTi-SP catalysts was exhibited in Fig. 13 . The specific description was as follows: (1) The NH3-SCR reaction over the three catalysts all might obey the L-H and E-R mechanisms. (2) NH3 (L) species and NH4 + (B) species adsorbed on catalysts surface were consumed in reaction with gaseous NO, which could be described as E-R mechanism (Pathway 1). NH3 (L) species on CeNbTi-IM catalyst were consumed faster than the other two catalysts. It suggested that NH3 (L) species played a crucial role as a major intermediate. (3) For L-H mechanism, the existence of adsorbed NO2 was highly conducive to the low-temperature SCR activity via the “fast-SCR”, and facilitated the formation of the intermediate nitrate species (Pathway 2). Finally, it was also possible that there was a productive reaction between adsorbed NH3 and pre-adsorbed NO x species (Pathway 3). 4 Conclusions Ce-Nb-Ti oxides were synthesized by an impregnation, co-precipitation and solid process method. Different preparation methods lead to different surface structure characteristics of catalysts, crystallinity of oxides, dispersion of active components and chemical states of the surface species. More importantly, the reduction capacity of CeNbTi catalysts and the number and strength of acid sites were also significantly different. In addition, the activation and reactivity of gas molecules on the surface of CeNbTi catalysts were different. The combination of all these factors made CeNbTi catalysts finally show a significant difference in catalytic activity. CeNbTi-IM possessed the best deNO x performance in a wide temperature range in different GHSV, and excellent resistance to SO2 and K2O. The CeNbTi catalyst prepared by impregnation method has proper surface characteristics, strong interspecies interaction and homogeneous dispersion of active species. The impregnation method was demonstrated to be beneficial to increase the concentration of Ce3+ and chemisorbed oxygen on the CeNbTi catalyst surface while increase the number of Lewis acid sites and enhance redox ability. From the results of in situ DRIFTS, the impregnation method was favorable for the adsorption of a larger amount of weakly adsorbed NO2, bidentate nitrate and NH3 species with better reactivity. It was revealed that the reaction paths over CeNbTi-IM, CeNbTi-CP and CeNbTi-SP obeyed both Langmuir-Hinshelwood and Eley-Rideal mechanisms, but the impregnation method could accelerate the reaction of pre-adsorbed ammonia/NO x species and NO x species/ammonia. coredata.dc:description: Ce-Nb-Ti metal oxide catalysts (CeNbTi) were synthesized for NH3-SCR by impregnation (IM), co-precipitation (CP) and solid process (SP) methods and characterized by various techniques. The results of NH3-SCR activity evaluations showed that CeNbTi-IM possessed the superior NH3-SCR performance in different gas hourly space velocity and better resistance to SO2 and potassium. The characterization results showed that the CeNbTi-IM catalyst had relatively high concentrations of Ce3+ and chemisorbed oxygen, strong synergistic effect among different components and well dispersed active species. More importantly, the catalyst had stronger reduction capacity and a large number of Lewis acid sites, which contributed to its excellent catalytic performance. The in situ DRIFTS results revealed that the impregnation method was beneficial to the adsorption of weakly adsorbed NO2, bidentate nitrate and NH3 species. In addition, it was revealed that the reaction paths over CeNbTi-IM, CeNbTi-CP and CeNbTi-SP obeyed both Langmuir-Hinshel wood and Eley-Rideal mechanisms, but the impregnation method could accelerate the reaction between pre-adsorbed ammonia/NO x species and NO x species/ammonia.
coredata.dc:title: Comparative study of Ce-Nb-Ti oxide catalysts prepared by different methods for selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3
